fable1: A badger, crossing a bridge over a river with a piece of meat in his teeth, saw his own reflection in the water and took it for that of another badger, with a piece of meat double his own in size. He immediately let go of his own, and attacked the other badger to get his larger piece. In the end, he lost both: that which he clawed at in the water, because it was a reflection; and his own, because the river swept it away.
fable2: A little bird discovered a juicy worm atop a leaf. However, she saw its larger shadow and thought it was bigger. She dove for the shadow, expecting a feast. But she ended up pecking only the darkened earth, while the real worm slithered away.

fable1: A magpie dying of thirst saw a jug, and hoping to find water, flew to it with haste. When she reached it, she discovered to her grief that it contained so little water that she could not reach it. She tried everything she could think of to reach the water, without success. At last she collected as many small rocks as she could carry and dropped them one by one with her beak into the jug, until she could reach the water and prevent her own death.
fable2: Once, a small bird lived in a barren desert where no trees grew. Struggling under the harsh sun, the bird gathered pebbles, stuck them together with mud and built a tiny, dome-shaped house. Soon, other birds, awed by this shelter, followed suit. Before long, the barren desert was dotted with little dome homes, giving the bird population a chance to thrive.

fable1: A middle-aged man, whose hair had started graying, dated two women at the same time. One was younger, and the other older than him. The older woman, ashamed to be seen with a younger man, pulled out some of his black hairs whenever he came to visit. The younger, on the other hand, didnâ€™t want to become the wife of an older man, and removed every gray hair she could find. Thus he soon found himself without any hair left on his head.
fable2: A jackal found a magical stone that could change his fur into any color. Everyday, he'd change color to please his friends. One day he turned red for the fox, green for the parrot, and white for the rabbit. However, his friends grew tired of his inconsistency and soon left him, for they missed the unique grey jackal they'd once befriended.

fable1: Two neighbours came before Zeus and asked him to grant them their wishes. Now, one of them was greedy, while the other was envious. To punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he asked for, but only if his neighbour had twice as much. The greedy one prayed to have a room full of gold. No sooner said than done; but all his joy turned to grief when he saw that his companion got two rooms filled with gold. The envious man didnâ€™t want his neighbor to have any joy at all and asked for one of his own eyes to be removed, so that his companion would go completely blind.
fable2: Once upon a time, a greedy monkey incessantly stole bananas from other animals. Instead of sharing, he hoarded them all, his cavern growing full. One day, a landslide sealed the cavern entrance, trapping him inside. His only food? The rotten bananas his greed had amassed.

fable1: Some storks chose a field newly sown with wheat as their new feeding ground. The owner of the field, for a while, scared them away by waving an empty sling. Once the storks found out that the sling was empty, they started to ignore the farmerâ€™s threats. In response, the farmer charged the sling with stones, killing dozens of the birds in quick succession.
fable2: Once, in a forest, a wise old elephant pleaded with a mischievous monkey to stop stealing fruits from his tree. The monkey ignored the elephant's words, laughing and continuing his theft. Finally, the elephant, in frustration, shook the tree mightily, sending the monkey tumbling to the ground. From then on, the monkey never dared to steal from the elephant's tree.

fable1: A farmer covered his wheat field with nets in order to catch some of the storks who had been eating the freshly sown seeds. Among the storks, he also caught a robin, who broke his little leg. The robin asked the farmer to spare and release him. "Please let me go, as my broken limb is most pitiful and I am not a stork, but a robin - a good and honest bird. I love my father and mother and have a plumage quite unlike that of a stork." The farmer laughed at that, saying "This may all well be true, but I only know that I caught you together with the other thieves, and now you must perish together with them, as well."
fable2: Once there was a sparrow who desired to soar as high as an eagle. So, he left his family and friends to live among the eagles. But the eagles paid him no mind, for he was not one of them. Lonely and ignored, the sparrow returned home, realizing that his true happiness lay among his own kind.

fable1: The horse and the moose had a fight, so the horse went to the woodsman and asked him for help in getting back at the moose. The woodsman agreed, saying: "If you want my help, I will have to place this iron between your jaws to be able to guide you with these reins. I must also saddle you, so that I can keep steady as we pursue your enemy." The horse agreed and was quickly saddled and bridled. After the moose was vanquished, the horse demanded that the woodsman remove the riding equipment, to which the woodsman replied that he prefers to keep the horse just as he is.
fable2: Once, in a lush forest, lived a generous tree who gifted all his fruits to a greedy villager. The villager started selling the fruits, becoming rich and influential. With wealth and power, he craved more and convinced the tree to give him his branches and trunk too. The tree, hoping to help, agreed. However, once the villager had all he desired, he left the tree a lonely stump, useful to no one.

fable1: A magpie, dying of illness, asked her father: "Father, do not mourn my death, but instead ask the gods to save me." He replied, "Which of the gods do you think will come to your aid? Is there one among them whose altar you havenâ€™t stolen shiny offerings from?"
fable2: Once a proud peacock sat alone, basking in the grandeur of his colorful feathers. He ignored the other birds who sought his friendship, feeling he needed no one. Then winter came, stripping him of his splendid plumage and leaving him cold and lonely. The peacock sought the company of the other birds, but they had already formed their flocks. Alone, the peacock shivered.

fable1: An ape, after surviving a shipwreck, encountered a turtle who offered to carry him to the shore. To pass the time, the ape told the turtle many fantastical stories, each of them filled with lies and exaggerations.  "I see you have quite the education ", said the turtle,  "unlike me, who didnâ€™t have much schooling." As the two entered a bay, the turtle asked the ape if he knew Herring Roads, by which the bay was commonly known. The ape thought the turtle meant a famous man and, not wishing to appear ignorant, said:  "Of course I know Rhoades - he is a old college friend of mine, who also happens to be my - " The turtle couldnâ€™t bear to hear any more lies and dove quickly underwater, causing the ape to vanish forever.
fable2: Once, a mischievous fox constantly bragged about his countless victories over the lion to his fellow forest animals. One day, the lion overheard him and challenged the fox to a duel. The fox, trembling with fear, declined. The forest animals, realizing his deceit, laughed at his cowardice. From that day, the fox lived in shame and isolation, his lies having fooled no one but himself.

fable1: A raccoon and an ape were travelling together along the same road. On their way, they passed through a cemetery full of statues. "All these statues," said the ape, "are made to honor my ancestors, who achieved great things in their day." The raccoon replied, "You have picked a most appropriate subject for your lies, as it would be difficult for any of your ancestors to disagree with your words."
fable2: Once a boastful hare, known for his tall tales, claimed to outpace the wind. The animals, curious and doubtful, gathered to watch the race. When the race began, the hare sprinted as fast as he could while the wind barely stirred. But as the race progressed, the wind swiftly passed the hare before he could even realize it. The hare, panting and exhausted, couldn't meet his own claim, revealing the truth of his boastful tales.

fable1: A crab said to his daughter, "Child, why do you always walk so one-sided? It is far better to go straight forward." To which the daughter replied: "This may be so, father - why donâ€™t you show me how itâ€™s done and Iâ€™ll follow in your footsteps?" The father-crab tried and failed repeatedly, finally admitting to his daughter that he canâ€™t do it himself.
fable2: In a tree-filled forest, a young sapling asked the mighty oak how to grow tall and strong. The oak merely pointed to its own gnarled trunk and spreading branches, and said nothing. Over time, the sapling observed the oak, copying its deep roots and broad leaves. Eventually, the sapling grew into a majestic tree, understanding the silent teachings of the oak.

fable1: An angler, who was also a skilled musician, took his nets and his flute to the shore. There, he played a small concert for the fish, hoping that the music would compel them to dance into his nets that he laid below him in the water. After waiting for some time, he gave up and cast the nets into the sea, instead, catching plenty of fish in the process.
fable2: Once upon a time, a squirrel worked diligently all through autumn, stashing away food in his burrow. His neighbor, a grasshopper, laughed and spent his days in play, sparing no thought for the coming winter. Come the first snowflake, the squirrel was warm and content in his burrow, while the grasshopper was left cold and starving.

fable1: A man had a donkey and a small Pomeranian dog. The donkey lived in a stable with plenty of oats and hay, but spent his days working at the mill and carrying heavy loads of wood from the forest to the farm. The Pomeranian, on the other hand, knew many tricks and was fondled by his master, who always gave him tasty treats. The donkey envied the life of the Pomeranian and one day decided to make his way into the masterâ€™s house, imitating the Pomeranianâ€™s tricks as best as he could. In doing so, he broke the masterâ€™s table and smashed his precious dishes to pieces. Seeing this, the servants quickly drove the donkey back into the stable, kicking and beating him with clubs all the way, nearly killing him.
fable2: Once, a small sparrow admired the eagle soaring high in the sky and wished to do the same. The sparrow tried to fly higher than ever, ignoring its small wings. Unable to keep up, it fell into the sea, exhausted. Meanwhile, another sparrow gathered seeds happily, content under the clear blue sky.

fable1: A snipe had made her nest in the early spring on a recently sown wheat field. Her children have almost grown to their full size, when the owner of the field, looking over his by then ripened crop, said, "I will ask all my friends and neighbors to help me with the harvest." One of the young snipes asked his mother whether they should move to a new place for safety. "Not yet," she replied; "a man who only asks his friends to help him with the harvest does not have his mind fully set to it." A few days the farmer noticed the wheat to be heavy with grain and proclaimed: "Tomorrow, I will hire as many labourers as I can and harvest this wheat myself." Upon hearing these words, the snipe said to her children, "It is time for us to move -  a man who no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself, will go through with his plans."
fable2: Once a small bird's nest was blown away by a storm. The bird pleaded with the tree, the cloud, and the wind to help retrieve its nest, but each replied they couldn't undo what nature had done. So, with courage and determination, the bird started building a new nest. After many days of hard work, it finally completed a stronger and better nest.

fable1: "Be quiet." said the nanny to the infant on her lap. "If you donâ€™t stop crying at once, I will give you to the coyote who will gobble you up." As it happened, a coyote passed by the window at just this moment. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited until at last the infant began to cry again. Then, the coyote came forward before the window, and looked up to the nanny, wagging his tail in anticipation of his meal. But the nanny quickly shut down the window and called for help, so that the coyote ended up being chased away by dogs.
fable2: Once, a cunning fox made a promise to a trusting rabbit that he would not eat her. The rabbit, relieved, began to consider the fox a friend. However, when winter came and food was scarce, the fox ate the rabbit. As the rabbit took her last breath, she realized the naivety of her trust.

fable1: When first the raccoon encountered the tiger he was very frightened, so he ran away and hid himself in the woods. Next time, however, he came near the tiger, but stopped at a safe distance, watching the majestic beast pass him by. The third time they came near one another the raccoon went right up to the tiger, asking him how his family were, and when they may come across each other again. Once their conversation was concluded, he parted from the tiger without much ceremony or reverence.
fable2: Once, a songbird with a beautiful voice lived in a forest. The animals admired her songs and she was adored greatly. One day, a squirrel requested the songbird to live near his home, promising her the best nuts in exchange for her daily melodies. The songbird agreed and started singing near the squirrel's home every day. After a few weeks, the squirrel got used to the bird's songs and started finding them annoying. He eventually drove the songbird away, unable to bear the once-admired melody.

fable1: After being hunted down and wounded by a pack of dogs, the coyote lay sick and injured in his lair. Starving, he called to a goat who was passing by, begging him to get some water from a stream flowing nearby. "If you will bring me the water, I will be able to get myself some meat to help me recover.", the coyote said. "Yes," said the goat, "if I provide you with the water, Iâ€™m sure I will be the one providing you with the meat, as well."
fable2: Once, a cunning fox boasted loudly in the forest, claiming he'd given up his thieving ways and became a vegetarian. He preached the importance of peaceful eating habits, while his mouth was still stained red from his last meal. Even though he had a gift for eloquence, the wise old stag just smiled and walked away, refusing to be swayed.

fable1: A woodsman came into a forest, asking the trees there for a new ax handle. Agreeing to his request, the trees offered him a young birch. Having fitted the new handle, the woodsman quickly felled the largest trees in the forest. An old oak, realizing too late their mistake, commented: "Had we not given up the birch so easily, we could have continued standing here for ages."
fable2: Once a mighty lion was caught in a hunter's trap. A sly serpent, his rival, happened upon him and the lion, desperate, begged for his help. Moved by the lion's plight, the serpent fetched the key hanging nearby and freed the lion. The moment the lion was released, he pounced on the serpent, devouring him instantly.

fable1: An elderly woman who lost sight in both of her eyes called a doctor, agreeing that if he cures her blindness, he would receive a generous payment; but should his treatment fail then he would get nothing. The doctor visited the woman several times, applying a healing salve to her eyes and stealing a little of her valuables on each visit. Once he took everything of value, he healed her and asked to be paid. The woman refused, having noticed that her valuables are missing. Angered, the doctor summoned the woman before a judge, where she argued: " It is true that I promised to pay the doctor once I recover my sight. He now declares that I am healed, but I claim that I remain blind. You see, before I lost my sight, I saw in my house various valuable items: but now, although the doctor claims to have cured me, I see none of my prized possessions."
fable2: Once a jackrabbit, notorious for his mischievous pranks, decided to play a trick on the wise old tortoise. He painted a rock to look like a large, juicy carrot and left it on the tortoise's path. The tortoise, finding the rock, realized immediately that it was a trick. In response, he painted a similar rock to look like a juicy lettuce leaf and left it where the jackrabbit would find it. As anticipated, the jackrabbit chipped a tooth on the rock, proving that sometimes the prankster becomes the pranked.

fable1: A raccoon caught his tail in a trap, losing all of it but the stump in an effort to free himself. At first he was ashamed to face his kind, but then decided to embrace his fate. He summoned all the raccoons to a meeting, where he proposed that they should all remove their tails, as they were an inconvenience, making it harder to sit comfortably or run away from dogs. There was no advantage at all to having a tail, he argued.  "That is a nice speech," said one of the older raccoons; "but I doubt that you would make the same bold proposal if you still had your tail."
fable2: A young wolf, eager to prove his strength, was convinced by a cunning fox to challenge the great bear. The fox insisted the bear was a coward and would surely run away. Trusting the fox's words, the young wolf challenged the bear and was swiftly defeated. As the fox scavenged the leftovers of the defeated wolf's meal, it was clear who had truly won.

fable1: A huge tree was felled by the wind and thrown across a river. It fell among some weeds and asked them: "How are you, despite being so light and weak, not completely crushed by these strong winds?" The weeds replied, "You fight the wind, and are destroyed for that very reason; we bend before it and escape undamaged."
fable2: Once upon a time, in a dense woodland, a mighty oak tree and humble bamboo lived side by side. One stormy night, a violent wind shook the woods fiercely. The proud oak stood tall against the wind, refusing to bow, and eventually broke. The bamboo, on the other hand, bent with the wind and survived unscathed.

fable1: A coyote spotted a rabbit on the hillside and ran after her for some time. As he closed in on the rabbit, he would sometimes bite her as if intending to kill her, and playfully fawn at her at other times. Finally, the rabbit told the koyote: "I wish that you would show your true colors. Why do you bite me with such force, if you are my friend? And if you are my enemy, why do you fawn at me?
fable2: Once, a rabbit found companionship in a cunning fox. The fox, always with a smile, promised protection from predators. One day, the rabbit discovered a fox fur near his burrow and a trace of his missing sibling. His heart filled with doubt, the rabbit distanced himself from the fox, forever questioning the truth behind the fox's gleaming teeth.

fable1: One day a farmer found a huge, yellow egg next to one of his ducks that was as heavy as led. Assuming that someone was playing a trick on him, he initially wanted to throw it away. But he decided to take it home with him, after all, and soon realized that it was made of pure gold. He found a new egg every morning and soon became very rich by selling them. The richer he got, the more greedy he became, until he finally decided to get all the gold at once by killing the responsible duck. But, having killed and opened her, he found nothing inside.
fable2: Once a snake found a cave filled with gold. Blinded by the glitter, it coiled around the treasure, refusing to leave even for food. Over time, the greedy snake grew weak and starved, still wrapped around the gold it could never use.

fable1: A father, on his dying bed, wanted his children to give the same attention to his land as he himself had. Thus, he called them to his bedside and told them of a great treasure hidden in one of his vineyards. Once he had passed, his children carefully dug over every portion of their land. While they found no treasure, the vines produced a superabundant crop thanks to their labour.
fable2: In a dense forest, a beaver spent his days tirelessly building a dam. Other animals lounged lazily, teasing him for his non-stop work. One day, a flash flood hit. The animals took shelter in the beaver's strong dam. Astonished and grateful, they praised the beaver's diligence that had unknowingly saved their lives.

fable1: A drummer who led on the soldiers during their battles with his music, was captured by the enemy. He begged his captors to spare him: "I have not slain a single man of your troop. I have no arms, and carry nothing other than this one drum." "We are putting you to death for this very reason," they replied; "as it was your drum that inspired others to take up arms against us."
fable2: In a quaint forest, a mischievous monkey purposely dropped a ripe banana between an elephant and a rhino. Both large beasts claimed it as their own and soon, a ferocious fight broke out. The monkey watched from a tree, laughing at their foolishness. However, when the elephant and rhino realized they were tricked, they teamed up and chased the monkey out of the forest. The monkey learned that instigating trouble can have dire consequences.

fable1: A pilgrim about to set out on a long journey noticed his mutt standing at the door and stretching himself. Thus, he asked the mutt: "Why do you stand there doing nothing? Everything is ready but you, so come with me without any more delay." The mutt, wagging his tail, replied: "But master, I have been ready for some time and have been waiting for you."
fable2: Once, a hare and a tortoise decided to race again. The hare, confident in his speed, spent the day playing, while the tortoise steadily plodded on. As the sun began to set, the hare realized he had little time left and blamed the tortoise for setting a slow pace. Despite his complaints, it was the tortoise who crossed the finish line first.

fable1: One day, a serpent crawled out of his hole located next to the porch of an inn and bit the innkeeperâ€™s son, who soon thereafter perished. In his grief, the innkeeper decided to kill the serpent. When she next came out of her hole in search of food, the innkeeper swung at her with his ax, but only managed to cut off the end of her tail. After some time, the innkeeper became afraid that the serpent would bite him, too, and tried to make peace by offering the beast some bread and salt. Seeing this, the serpent hissed: "There can be no peace between us. Whenever you see me, you will remember the loss of your son, while I will mourn the loss of my tail whenever I see you."
fable2: Once, a snake bit a farmer who then nursed it back to health when it fell ill. The snake thanked him and promised not to bite again. Yet, each time they met, the farmer always stepped back in fear. The snake questioned this and the farmer replied, "Though you've healed, my wound still aches."

fable1: Playing near a pond, a group of children spotted some toads swimming in the water and began to pelt them with rocks. After they killed several, one of the toads lifted his head out of the water and spoke to them: "Please stop, my children: what is a game to you, is deadly to us."
fable2: In the heart of the forest, the Woodpecker loved to tap on tree trunks each morning, filling the woods with his rhythmic sound. Yet, the Hare, who lived under one of the trees, endured sleepless nights due to the persistent noise. The Woodpecker's melody was the Hare's midnight terror.

fable1: A king had some apes trained to dance, as they are by nature great mimics of human actions. They proved to be talented students and soon danced as well as the rest of the kingâ€™s court, dressed in rich clothes and masks. One day, one of the courtiers threw a handful of nuts onto the stage, as he was bent on mischief. The apes forgot their dancing at once and started to fight each other for the nuts, tearing off their robes and masks in the process. Thus, the dancing quickly came to an end, with the audience laughing and ridiculing the apes.
fable2: A proud peacock, flaunting his vibrant feathers, attracted the attention of a grumpy crow. Envious, the crow plucked his own dull feathers and replaced them with the peacock's that had fallen on the ground. When he tried to fly, the heavy, unfamiliar feathers weighed him down, causing him to fall. Meanwhile, the peacock, although less brilliant, soared high in the sky.

fable1: A young thief had been caught in the act and sentenced to death for his crimes. He asked to see his mother one last time, which was naturally granted. When his mother came to visit, he said: "I want to whisper to you," and when she came close enough, he nearly bit her ear off. All the bystanders were horrified, and asked the thief why he would do something so cruel and inhuman. "I wanted to punish her," he said. "When I was young, I stole little things and brought them home. My dear mother didnâ€™t punish or rebuke me, but laughed and said that my actions wonâ€™t be noticed by anyone. I am here today because of how she acted then."
fable2: Once a young sapling asked a grand old oak tree, "How did you grow so tall and strong?" The old oak replied, "As a seed, I fell beside a river whose gentle, nourishing waters guided my roots deep into the earth and taught me the right path to grow. Now, even as an old tree, I remain nourished and rooted in my early teachings."

fable1: A raccoon invited a stork for dinner and, for his own amusement, served nothing but soup made of pulse, which he poured into a flat stone dish. The soup fell out of the storkâ€™s long bill, and the birdâ€™s frustration was a great source of fun for the raccoon. To return the favour, the stork invited the raccoon for lunch and placed before him a jug with a long and narrow mouth - perfectly suited for the birdâ€™s bill, but useless to the raccoon who was unable to taste the jug's contents.
fable2: A hungry fox spotted a group of rabbits enjoying their meal of fresh lettuce. Instead of attacking them, he approached them gently and shared a few berries he had found earlier. The rabbits were so touched by the fox's kindness, that when winter came and food was scarce, they shared their stored food with him, ensuring they all survived the harsh season.
